title: Deformations of curves with constant curvature

sections.text:
## MOHAMMAD GHOMI AND MATTEO RAFFAELLI
#### Abstract

We prove that curves of constant curvature satisfy the parametric $\mathcal{C}^{1}$-dense relative $h$-principle in the space of immersed curves with nonvanishing curvature in Euclidean space $\mathbf{R}^{n \geq 3}$. It follows that two knots of constant curvature in $\mathbf{R}^{3}$ are isotopic, resp. homotopic, through curves of constant curvature if and only if they are isotopic, resp. homotopic, and their self-linking numbers, resp. self-linking numbers $\bmod 2$, are equal.

## 1. INTRODUCTION

The homotopy and isotopy classes of closed curves with nonvanishing curvature in Euclidean space $\mathbf{R}^{n}$ have been classified in terms of their self-linking number $[5,12,21]$. In this work we obtain parallel results for curves of constant curvature by an approximation argument.

To state our main result, let $\Gamma$ be an interval $[a, b] \subset \mathbf{R}$ or the topological circle $\mathbf{R} /((b-a) \mathbf{Z})$, and $\mathcal{C}^{k}\left(\Gamma, \mathbf{R}^{n}\right)$ be the space of $\mathcal{C}^{k}$ maps $f: \Gamma \rightarrow \mathbf{R}^{n}$ with its standard topology induced by the $\mathcal{C}^{k}$-norm $|\cdot|_{k}$. We say that $f_{0}, f_{1} \in \mathcal{C}^{k}\left(\Gamma, \mathbf{R}^{n}\right)$ are $\mathcal{C}^{\ell \leq k}$-homotopic if there is a family $f_{t} \in \mathcal{C}^{\ell}\left(\Gamma, \mathbf{R}^{n}\right)$, for $t \in[0,1]$, such that $t \mapsto f_{t}$ is continuous. Then $f_{t}$ is a called a $\mathcal{C}^{\ell}$-homotopy. The space of (immersed) curves $\operatorname{Imm}^{k}\left(\Gamma, \mathbf{R}^{n}\right) \subset \mathcal{C}^{k}\left(\Gamma, \mathbf{R}^{n}\right)$ consists of locally injective maps with nonvanishing derivative when $k \geq 1$. The curvature of $f \in \operatorname{Imm}^{2}\left(\Gamma, \mathbf{R}^{n}\right)$ is given by $\kappa:=\left|T^{\prime}\right| /\left|f^{\prime}\right|$, where $T:=f^{\prime} /\left|f^{\prime}\right|$ is the tantrix of $f$.

Theorem 1.1. Let $f_{t} \in \operatorname{Imm}^{k \geq 2}\left(\Gamma, \mathbf{R}^{n \geq 3}\right)$ be a $\mathcal{C}^{2}$-homotopy of curves with nonvanishing curvature. Suppose that $f_{0}$ and $f_{1}$ have constant curvature. Then, for any $\varepsilon>0$, there exists a $\mathcal{C}^{2}$-homotopy $\widetilde{f}_{t} \in \operatorname{Imm}^{k}\left(\Gamma, \mathbf{R}^{n}\right)$ of curves with constant curvature such that $\widetilde{f}_{0}=f_{0}, \widetilde{f}_{1}=f_{1}$, and $\left|\widetilde{f}_{t}-f_{t}\right|_{1} \leq \varepsilon$. Furthermore, if $f_{t}$ have unit speed, then $\widetilde{f}_{t}$ may be tangent to $f_{t}$ at any finite set of points prescribed in $\Gamma$.

In the terminology of Gromov [13] or Eliashberg-Mishachev [4], the result above establishes a parametric $\mathcal{C}^{1}$-dense relative $h$-principle for curves of constant curvature in the space of curves with nonvanishing curvature. The nonparametric version, which states that curves of constant curvature are dense in $\operatorname{Imm}^{k \geq 2}\left(\Gamma, \mathbf{R}^{n}\right)$ with respect to the $\mathcal{C}^{1}$-norm, had been obtained earlier in [8].

We say that $f \in \mathcal{C}^{k}\left(\Gamma, \mathbf{R}^{n}\right)$ is closed when $\Gamma$ is a circle. If closed curves $f_{0}$, $f_{1} \in \operatorname{Imm}^{k \geq 2}\left(\Gamma, \mathbf{R}^{3}\right)$ with nonvanishing curvature are $\mathcal{C}^{2}$-homotopic through curves with nonvanishing curvature, then their tantrices $T_{0}, T_{1}$ are $\mathcal{C}^{1}$-homotopic. Feldman

[5] proved the converse of this phenomenon, via Smale's extension [24] of WhitneyGraustein theorem [29] to spherical curves. Furthermore, Rosenberg [21] showed that $T_{0}$ and $T_{1}$ are $\mathcal{C}^{1}$-homotopic if and only if $\mathrm{SL}_{2}\left(f_{0}\right)=\mathrm{SL}_{2}\left(f_{1}\right)$, where $\mathrm{SL}_{2}$ denotes the self-linking number $\bmod 2$. Thus Theorem 1.1 yields:

Corollary 1.2. A pair of closed curves $f_{0}, f_{1} \in \operatorname{Imm}^{k \geq 2}\left(\Gamma, \mathbf{R}^{3}\right)$ of constant curvature are $\mathcal{C}^{2}$-homotopic through $\mathcal{C}^{k}$ curves of constant curvature if and only if $\mathrm{SL}_{2}\left(f_{0}\right)=$ $\mathrm{SL}_{2}\left(f_{1}\right)$.

Let $\operatorname{Emb}^{k}\left(\Gamma, \mathbf{R}^{n}\right) \subset \operatorname{Imm}^{k}\left(\Gamma, \mathbf{R}^{n}\right)$ denote the space of injective or embedded curves. A pair of curves $f_{0}, f_{1} \in \operatorname{Emb}^{k}\left(\Gamma, \mathbf{R}^{n}\right)$ are $\mathcal{C}^{k}$-isotopic if they can be joined by a $\mathcal{C}^{k}$-homotopy $f_{t} \in \operatorname{Emb}^{k}\left(\Gamma, \mathbf{R}^{n}\right)$. A knot is an embedded closed curve $f \in \operatorname{Emb}^{0}\left(\Gamma, \mathbf{R}^{3}\right)$. Gluck and Pan [12] showed that two knots of nonvanishing curvature $f_{0}, f_{1} \in \operatorname{Emb}^{k \geq 2}\left(\Gamma, \mathbf{R}^{n}\right)$ are $\mathcal{C}^{2}$-isotopic through knots of nonvanishing curvature if and only if they are $\mathcal{C}^{0}$-isotopic and $\operatorname{SL}\left(f_{0}\right)=\operatorname{SL}\left(f_{1}\right)$, i.e., they have the same self-linking number. If $f_{t}$ in Theorem 1.1 is an isotopy, then (choosing $\varepsilon$ sufficiently small) we may assume that $\widetilde{f}_{t}$ is an isotopy as well. Thus we obtain:

Corollary 1.3. A pair of knots $f_{0}, f_{1} \in \operatorname{Emb}^{k \geq 2}\left(\Gamma, \mathbf{R}^{3}\right)$ of constant curvature are $\mathcal{C}^{2}$-isotopic through $\mathcal{C}^{k}$ knots of constant curvature if and only if they are $\mathcal{C}^{0}$-isotopic and $\operatorname{SL}\left(f_{0}\right)=\operatorname{SL}\left(f_{1}\right)$.

So the $\mathcal{C}^{2}$ homotopy and isotopy classes of closed curves of constant curvature in $\mathbf{R}^{3}$ mirror those of closed curves with nonvanishing curvature. In other words, a loop of constant curvature is just as flexible as one without inflection points. The self-linking number of a knot $f \in \operatorname{Emb}^{2}\left(\Gamma, \mathbf{R}^{3}\right)$ with nonvanishing curvature is the linking number of $f$ with a perturbation of $f$ along its principal normal $N:=T / \kappa$. The self-linking number $\bmod 2$ of a closed curve $f \in \operatorname{Imm}^{2}\left(\Gamma, \mathbf{R}^{3}\right)$ with nonvanishing curvature is the self-linking number $\bmod 2$ of a perturbation of $f$ to an embedded curve. See $[12,20,21]$ for more background and references on self-linking number.

The proof of Theorem 1.1 utilizes the fact that, when $\left|f_{t}^{\prime}\right|=1$, the curvature of $f_{t}$ is the speed of its tantrix $T_{t}$. Thus we approximate $T_{t}$ with a homotopy $\widetilde{T}_{t}$ of curves with constant speed, and set $\widetilde{f}_{t}(s):=\int_{a}^{s} \widetilde{T}_{t}(u) d u$. For $\widetilde{f}_{t}$ to be closed when $f_{t}$ is closed, we need to have $\int_{\Gamma} \widetilde{T}_{t}=\int_{\Gamma} T_{t}$. To this end, we construct $\widetilde{T}_{t}$ by creating sinusoidal bumps near suitably chosen points along $T_{t}$, via parametric versions of classical theorems of Carathéodory and Steinitz. The bumps have to be long enough to control $\int_{\Gamma} \widetilde{T}_{t}$, while vanishing sufficiently fast as $t \rightarrow 0,1$ to ensure that $\widetilde{T}_{t}$ is a $\mathcal{C}^{1}$-homotopy. Implementing this plan is particularly subtle when the convex hull of $T_{0}$ or $T_{1}$ has no interior points, as we will discuss below.

Constructing closed curves of constant curvature, by integrating spherical curves, goes back to Fenchel [6], and belongs to the convex integration theory [4, 7, 13, 25], which includes works by Whitney [29] and Nash-Kuiper [17, 19]. A nonparametric version of the above argument had been developed in [8]; however, the perturbation method there is not suitable for obtaining a $\mathcal{C}^{1}$-homotopy of tantrices, and our present construction is fundamentally different. See also [11] for another nonparametric

approach, and $[1,10]$ for some other examples of parametric $h$-principle in Riemannian geometry.

Nontrivial $\mathcal{C}^{2}$ knots of constant curvature were first constructed by Koch and Engelhardt [16] by gluing helical segments. Using the same method, McAtee [18] obtained $\mathcal{C}^{2}$ knots in every isotopy class. Existence of $\mathcal{C}^{\infty}$ knots of constant curvature, in every isotopy class, was first established in [8] via convex integration. This approach was also used later by Wasem [27] to obtain an $h$-principle for $\mathcal{C}^{2}$ curves with prescribed curvature.

# 2. Reduction to a Local Problem 

We start by showing that Theorem 1.1 is a consequence of the following result which supplies additional information on the curvature of the desired homotopy $\widetilde{f}_{t}$ and can be applied to subintervals in any partition of $\Gamma$. Let $I:=[a, b[$. It is always assumed that $t \in[0,1]$ unless specified otherwise.
Theorem 2.1. Let $f_{t} \in \operatorname{Imm}^{k \geq 2}\left(I, \mathbf{R}^{n \geq 3}\right)$ be a $\mathcal{C}^{2}$-homotopy of unit speed curves with nonvanishing curvature $\kappa_{t}$. Suppose that $\kappa_{0}$ and $\kappa_{1}$ are constant. Then for any $\varepsilon>0$ there exists a $\mathcal{C}^{2}$-homotopy $\widetilde{f}_{t} \in \operatorname{Imm}^{k}\left(I, \mathbf{R}^{n}\right)$ of unit speed curves with constant curvature $\widetilde{\kappa}_{t}$ such that
(1) $\widetilde{f}_{0}=f_{0}$ and $\widetilde{f}_{1}=f_{1}$,
(2) $\left|\widetilde{f}_{t}-f_{t}\right|_{1} \leq \varepsilon$,
(3) $\widetilde{f}_{t}=f_{t}$ on $\partial I$,
(4) $\widetilde{T}_{t}\left(\widetilde{U}_{t}\right)=T_{t}\left(U_{t}\right)$ for some neighborhoods $\widetilde{U}_{t}, U_{t}$ of $\partial I$.

Furthermore, $\widetilde{\kappa}_{t}$ may be set equal to any continuous function $c(t)$ such that $c(0)=\kappa_{0}$, $c(1)=\kappa_{1}, c(t)>\max \left(\kappa_{t}\right)$ for $t \in(0,1)$, and $c(t)$ is sufficiently large on $[\eta, 1-\eta]$ where $\eta>0$ is sufficiently small.

The last statement in the above theorem means that there exists $\bar{\eta}>0$ such that any $0<\eta \leq \bar{\eta}$ is admissible; and that for every such $\eta$ there exists a number $\bar{c}>0$ such that any function $c(t) \geq \bar{c}$ on $[\eta, 1-\eta]$ is admissible.

Suppose that Theorem 2.1 holds. Then Theorem 1.1 is established as follows. We may identify $\Gamma$ with $I$ by noting that $f_{t} \in \operatorname{Imm}^{k}\left(I, \mathbf{R}^{n}\right)$ is closed provided that $f_{t}(a)=f_{t}(b)$ and the derivatives $f_{t}^{(i)}(a)=f_{t}^{(i)}(b)$ for $i \leq k$. We may also assume that $f_{t}$ in Theorem 1.1 has unit speed. Indeed after replacing $f_{t}$ with the rescalings $\left|I\right| f_{t} /$ length $\left(f_{t}\right)$, where $|I|=b-a$, we may assume that $f_{t}$ have constant length $|I|$. Then there exists a continuous family of diffeomorphisms $\theta_{t}: I \rightarrow I$ such that $f_{t} \circ \theta_{t}$ has unit speed. Now if we obtain a homotopy $\widetilde{f}_{t}$ with $\left|\widetilde{f}_{t}-f_{t} \circ \theta_{t}\right|_{1}$ sufficiently small, then it is easily seen that $\left|\widetilde{f}_{t} \circ \theta_{t}^{-1}-f_{t}\right|_{1}$ will also be small; see the proof of [8, Prop. 5.4]. Hence $\widetilde{f}_{t} \circ \theta_{t}^{-1}$ will be the desired homotopy.

To find $\widetilde{f}_{t}$, let $a=: s_{0}<\cdots<s_{N}:=b$ be any partition of $I$ which includes the points prescribed in $\Gamma$, and set $I_{i}:=\left[s_{i}, s_{i+1}\right]$. Let $f_{t}^{i}$ be the restriction of $f_{t}$ to $I_{i}$, and $c_{i}(t)$ be an admissible curvature function for deforming $f_{t}^{i}$ as described in Theorem 2.1. Then $c(t):=\sum_{i} c_{i}(t)$ will also be admissible. Applying Theorem 2.1 to $f_{t}^{i}$ with respect to $c(t)$ and $\varepsilon$, we obtain homotopies $\widetilde{f}_{t}^{i}$ such that $\left|\left(\widetilde{f}_{t}^{i}\right)^{\prime}\right|=1$,

$\left|\widetilde{f}_{t}^{i}-f_{t}^{i}\right|_{1} \leq \varepsilon$, and $\widetilde{f_{t}^{i}}$ have uniform constant curvature. Set $\widetilde{f}_{t}:=\widetilde{f}_{t}^{i}$ on $I_{i}$. We only need to check that $\widetilde{f}_{t}$ is $\mathcal{C}^{k}$. Then it follows immediately that $\left|\widetilde{f}_{t}-f_{t}\right|_{1} \leq \varepsilon$ and $\widetilde{f}_{t}$ has constant curvature as desired.

To see that $\widetilde{f}_{t}$ is $\mathcal{C}^{k}$, first note that by item (3) in Theorem 2.1, $\widetilde{f}_{t}^{i}=f_{t}^{i}=f_{t}$ on $\partial I_{i}$. Thus $\widetilde{f}_{t}$ is $\mathcal{C}^{0}$. Furthermore, since $\left|\left(\widetilde{f}_{t}^{i}\right)^{\prime}\right|=1, \widetilde{T}_{t}^{i}=\left(\widetilde{f}_{t}^{i}\right)^{\prime}$. So by item (4) in Theorem 2.1, $\left(\widetilde{f}_{t}^{i}\right)^{\prime}=\left(f_{t}^{i}\right)^{\prime}=f_{t}^{\prime}$ on $\partial I_{i}$, which shows that $\widetilde{f}_{t}$ is $\mathcal{C}^{1}$. In particular $\widetilde{T}_{t}=\widetilde{f}_{t}^{\prime}$ is well-defined. So it suffices to check that $\widetilde{T}_{t}$ is $\mathcal{C}^{k-1}$. Note that $\widetilde{T}_{t}$ is piecewise $\mathcal{C}^{k-1}$ since $\left.\widetilde{T}_{t}\right|_{I_{i}}=\widetilde{T}_{t}^{i}=\left(\widetilde{f}_{t}^{i}\right)^{\prime}$ and $\widetilde{f}_{t}^{i}$ is $\mathcal{C}^{k}$ by Theorem 2.1. Furthermore, by item (4) of Theorem 2.1, if $s_{i}$ lies in the interior of $I$, then there are neighborhoods $U_{i-1}$ and $U_{i}$ of $s_{i}$ in $I_{i-1}$ and $I_{i}$ respectively such that $\widetilde{T}_{t}\left(U_{i-1}\right)=T_{t}\left(U_{i-1}\right)$ and $\widetilde{T}_{t}\left(U_{i}\right)=T_{t}\left(U_{i}\right)$. Hence $\widetilde{T}_{t}$ is reparametrization of $T_{t}$ with constant speed on the neighborhood $U_{i-1} \cup U_{i}$ of $s_{i} \in I$. Since $T_{t}$ is $\mathcal{C}^{k-1}$, it follows that $\widetilde{T}_{t}$ is $\mathcal{C}^{k-1}$ near $s_{i}$. So $\widetilde{T}_{t}$ is $\mathcal{C}^{k-1}$ as claimed.

# 3. Approximation with Nonflat Curves 

Here we show that homotopies $f_{t} \in \operatorname{Imm}^{k}\left(I, \mathbf{R}^{n}\right)$ may be perturbed to assume a generic property, which we need in order to establish Theorem 2.1. First we record the following fact, which is a standard application of Thom's jet transversality theorem $[4,14]$.

Lemma 3.1. Let $f \in \mathcal{C}^{k \geq 1}\left(I, \mathbf{R}^{n}\right)$. Then for any $\varepsilon>0$ there exists $\bar{f} \in \operatorname{Imm}^{\infty}\left(I, \mathbf{R}^{n}\right)$ such that $|\bar{f}-f|_{k} \leq \varepsilon$ and the first $n$ derivatives of $\bar{f}$ are linearly independent except possibly at finitely many points of $I$.

Proof. Let $J^{n}\left(I, \mathbf{R}^{n}\right)=I \times \mathbf{R}^{n(n+1)}$ be the space of the $n$-jets of maps $f \in \mathcal{C}^{n}\left(I, \mathbf{R}^{n}\right)$. The $n$-jet $j^{n} f: I \rightarrow J^{n}\left(I, \mathbf{R}^{n}\right)$ is given by $j^{n} f(s)=\left(s, f(s), f^{\prime}(s), \ldots, f^{(n)}(s)\right)$. Let $A \subset J^{n}\left(I, \mathbf{R}^{n}\right)$ consist of elements whose last $n$-coordinates are linearly dependent. The set of last $n$ elements of $A$ may be identified with $n \times n$ matrices of rank less than $n$, which form a stratified space of dimension $n^{2}-1$ [4, p. 16]. So $\operatorname{dim}(A)=1+n+\left(n^{2}-1\right)$ or $\operatorname{codim}(A)=1$. By the jet transversality theorem, for an open dense set of maps $\bar{f} \in \mathcal{C}^{n}\left(I, \mathbf{R}^{n}\right), j^{n} \bar{f}$ is transversal to $A$. Since $\operatorname{dim}(I)=\operatorname{codim}(A), j^{n} \bar{f}$ may intersect $A$ only at a discrete set. Finally, since $\operatorname{Imm}^{\infty}\left(I, \mathbf{R}^{n}\right)$ is dense in $\mathcal{C}^{n}\left(I, \mathbf{R}^{n}\right)$ [14, Thm. 2.12], we may assume that $\bar{f} \in \operatorname{Imm}^{\infty}\left(I, \mathbf{R}^{n}\right)$.

A subset of $\mathbf{R}^{n}$ is nonflat if its convex hull has interior points. By abuse of notation, for any mapping $f \in \mathcal{C}^{k}\left(I, \mathbf{R}^{n}\right)$, we may write $f$ to refer to $f(I)$, when the meaning is clear from context, e.g., we say $f$ is nonflat, if $f(I)$ is nonflat. Note that if derivatives of $f \in \mathcal{C}^{n}\left(I, \mathbf{R}^{n}\right)$ are linearly independent up to order $n$, at some point $s \in I$, then $f$ is nonflat.
Proposition 3.2. Let $f_{t} \in \operatorname{Imm}^{k \geq 2}\left(I, \mathbf{R}^{n \geq 3}\right)$ be a $\mathcal{C}^{k}$-homotopy with nonvanishing curvature. Then, for any $\varepsilon>0$, there exists a $\mathcal{C}^{k}$ homotopy $\bar{f}_{t} \in \operatorname{Imm}^{k}\left(I, \mathbf{R}^{n}\right)$ with nonvanishing curvature such that $\bar{f}_{0}=f_{0}, \bar{f}_{1}=f_{1},\left|f_{t}-\bar{f}_{t}\right|_{k} \leq \varepsilon, \bar{f}_{t}$ is nonflat for $t \in(0,1)$, and $\bar{f}_{t}=f_{t}$ on a neighborhood of $\partial I$.

Proof. For $i \in \mathbf{Z}$ choose $t_{i} \in(0,1)$ with $t_{i}<t_{i+1}$ and $t_{i} \rightarrow 1$ or 0 as $i \rightarrow \infty$ or $-\infty$ respectively. By Lemma 3.1, there are curves $g_{t_{i}} \in \operatorname{Imm}^{\infty}\left(I, \mathbf{R}^{n}\right)$ such that every segment of $g_{t_{i}}$ is nonflat, and $\left|g_{t_{i}}-f_{t_{i}}\right|_{k} \rightarrow 0$ as $i \rightarrow \pm \infty$. For $\lambda \in[0,1]$, set

$$
\bar{f}_{(1-\lambda) t_{i}+\lambda t_{i+1}}:=(1-\lambda) g_{t_{i}}+\lambda g_{t_{i+1}}
$$

This defines a homotopy $\bar{f}_{t} \in \mathcal{C}^{\infty}\left(I, \mathbf{R}^{n}\right)$ for $t \in(0,1)$ with $\left|\bar{f}_{t}-f_{t}\right|_{k} \rightarrow 0$ as $t \rightarrow 1,0$. So setting $\bar{f}_{0}:=f_{0}$ and $\bar{f}_{1}:=f_{1}$ yields a $\mathcal{C}^{k}$-homotopy $\bar{f}_{t} \in \mathcal{C}^{k}\left(I, \mathbf{R}^{n}\right)$ for $t \in[0,1]$.

Since $t \mapsto\left|f_{t}\right|_{k}$ is continuous, by Lemma 3.1 we may choose $t_{i}$ and $g_{t_{i}}$ so that

$$
\left|f_{t}-f_{t^{\prime}}\right|_{k} \leq \delta, \text { for } t, t^{\prime} \in\left[t_{i}, t_{i+1}\right], \quad \text { and } \quad\left|g_{t_{i}}-f_{t_{i}}\right|_{k} \leq \delta
$$

for any given $\delta>0$. For $t \in\left[t_{i}, t_{i+1}\right]$ we may rewrite (1) as $\bar{f}_{t}=\left(1-\lambda_{t}\right) g_{t_{i}}+\lambda_{t} g_{t_{i+1}}$, where $\lambda_{t} \in[0,1]$ is the number such that $t=\left(1-\lambda_{t}\right) t_{i}+\lambda_{t} t_{i+1}$. Then,

$$
\begin{gathered}
\left|\bar{f}_{t}-f_{t}\right|_{k} \leq\left(1-\lambda_{t}\right)\left|g_{t_{i}}-f_{t}\right|_{k}+\lambda_{t}\left|g_{t_{i+1}}-f_{t}\right|_{k} \\
\leq\left|g_{t_{i}}-f_{t_{i}}\right|_{k}+\left|f_{t_{i}}-f_{t}\right|_{k}+\left|g_{t_{i+1}}-f_{t_{i+1}}\right|_{k}+\left|f_{t_{i+1}}-f_{t}\right|_{k} \leq 4 \delta
\end{gathered}
$$

So setting $\delta \leq \varepsilon / 4$, we obtain $\left|\bar{f}_{t}-f_{t}\right|_{k} \leq \varepsilon$ as desired. Then choosing $\varepsilon$ sufficiently small yields that $\bar{f}_{t} \in \operatorname{Imm}^{k}\left(I, \mathbf{R}^{n}\right)$ and $\bar{f}_{t}$ has nonvanishing curvature.

To make $\bar{f}_{t}$ nonflat, let $\phi: I \rightarrow[0,1]$ be a $\mathcal{C}^{\infty}$ step function with $\phi=0$ near 0 and $\phi=1$ near 1. Set $\bar{t}_{i}:=\left(t_{i}+t_{i+1}\right) / 2$, and $g_{\bar{t}_{i}}:=\phi g_{t_{i}}+(1-\phi) g_{t_{i+1}}$. Then $g_{\bar{t}_{i}}$ is nonflat, since it shares a segment with $g_{t_{i}}$. We have

$$
\left|g_{\bar{t}_{i}}-f_{\bar{t}_{i}}\right|_{k}=\left|\phi\left(g_{t_{i}}-g_{t_{i+1}}\right)+g_{t_{i+1}}-f_{\bar{t}_{i}}\right|_{k} \leq C\left|g_{t_{i}}-g_{t_{i+1}}\right|_{k}+\left|g_{t_{i+1}}-f_{\bar{t}_{i}}\right|_{k}
$$

where $C$ is a constant which depends only on $|\phi|_{k}$. Furthermore,

$$
\begin{gathered}
\left|g_{t_{i}}-g_{t_{i+1}}\right|_{k} \leq\left|g_{t_{i}}-f_{t_{i}}\right|_{k}+\left|f_{t_{i}}-f_{t_{i+1}}\right|_{k}+\left|f_{t_{i+1}}-g_{t_{i+1}}\right|_{k} \leq 3 \delta \\
\left|g_{t_{i+1}}-f_{\bar{t}_{i}}\right|_{k} \leq\left|g_{t_{i+1}}-f_{t_{i+1}}\right|_{k}+\left|f_{t_{i+1}}-f_{\bar{t}_{i}}\right|_{k} \leq 2 \delta
\end{gathered}
$$

So $\left|g_{\bar{t}_{i}}-f_{\bar{t}_{i}}\right|_{k} \leq(3 C+2) \delta$. Set $\delta \leq \varepsilon /(4(3 C+2))$, replace $\left\{t_{i}\right\}$ by a reindexing of $\left\{t_{i}, \bar{t}_{i}\right\}$, and let $\bar{f}_{t}$ be the corresponding homotopy given by (1). Then $\left|g_{t_{i}}-f_{t_{i}}\right|_{k} \leq \varepsilon / 4$ by (2), which yields $\left|\bar{f}_{t}-f_{t}\right|_{k} \leq \varepsilon$ by (3). Furthermore, $\bar{f}_{t}$ is now nonflat, since it shares a segment with $g_{t_{i}}$ or $g_{t_{i+1}}$, when $t \in\left[t_{i}, t_{i+1}\right]$. Finally, using a partition of unity on $I$, we may glue $\bar{f}_{t}$ to $f_{t}$ near $\partial I$.

# 4. The Length and Center of Mass of Spherical Curves 

Here we reduce Theorem 2.1 to a geometric result for nonflat spherical curves, which is applied to the tantrix of $f_{t}$. The center of mass and average of a curve $f \in \operatorname{Imm}^{1}\left(I, \mathbf{R}^{n}\right)$ are defined as

$$
\operatorname{cm}(f):=\frac{1}{\operatorname{length}(f)} \int_{I} f\left|f^{\prime}\right|, \quad \text { and } \quad \operatorname{ave}(f):=\frac{1}{|I|} \int_{I} f
$$

Note that $\mathrm{cm}(f)$ is invariant under reparametrizations of $f$, and when $\left|f^{\prime}\right|$ is constant, $\operatorname{cm}(f)=\operatorname{ave}(f)$. Let $\operatorname{conv}(f)$ denote the convex hull of $f$. If $f$ is nonflat, then $\mathrm{cm}(f)$ and $\operatorname{ave}(f)$ lie in the interior of $\operatorname{conv}(f)$ [8, Lem. 2.3] which is denoted by int $\operatorname{conv}(f)$. We say $f \in \mathcal{C}^{k}\left(I, \mathbf{S}^{n-1}\right)$ is nonflat if $f$ is nonflat in $\mathbf{R}^{n}$. Let $U_{\varepsilon}(f)$ denote the open neighborhood of $f$ of radius $\varepsilon$.

Theorem 4.1. Let $f_{t} \in \operatorname{Imm}^{k \geq 1}\left(I, \mathbf{S}^{n-1}\right)$ be a $\mathcal{C}^{1}$-isotopy of nonflat curves of length $\ell_{t}$, and $x:[0,1] \rightarrow \mathbf{R}^{n}$ be a continuous map with $x(t) \in \operatorname{int} \operatorname{conv}\left(f_{t}\right)$. Suppose that $x(0)=\operatorname{cm}\left(f_{0}\right)$ and $x(1)=\operatorname{cm}\left(f_{1}\right)$. Then for any $\varepsilon>0$ and natural number $m$, there exists a $\mathcal{C}^{1}$-isotopy $\widehat{f}_{t} \in \operatorname{Imm}^{k}\left(I, \mathbf{S}^{n+m-1}\right)$ such that
(1) $\widehat{f}_{0}=f_{0}$ and $\widehat{f}_{1}=f_{1}$,
(2) $\widehat{f}_{t} \subset U_{\varepsilon}\left(f_{t}\right)$,
(3) $\underline{\operatorname{cm}}\left(\widehat{f}_{t}\right)=x(t)$,
(4) $\widehat{f}_{t}=f_{t}$ on a neighborhood of $\partial I$,
(5) $\widehat{f}_{t}$ is nonflat in $\mathbf{R}^{n+m}$ for $t \in(0,1)$.

Furthermore, we may set length $\left(\widehat{f}_{t}\right)$ equal to any continuous function $\widetilde{\ell}_{t}$ such that $\widetilde{\ell}_{0}=\ell_{0}, \widetilde{\ell}_{1}=\ell_{1}, \widetilde{\ell}_{t}>\ell_{t}$ for $t \in(0,1)$, and $\widetilde{\ell}_{t}$ is sufficiently large on $[\eta, 1-\eta]$ where $\eta>0$ is sufficiently small.

The last statement in the above theorem means that there exists $\bar{\eta}>0$ such that any $0<\eta \leq \bar{\eta}$ is admissible; and that for every such $\eta$ there exists a number $\bar{\ell}>0$ such that any function $\widetilde{\ell}_{t} \geq \bar{\ell}$ on $[\eta, 1-\eta]$ is admissible.

To show that Theorem 2.1 follows from Theorem 4.1, first we record:
Corollary 4.2. Let $f_{0} \in \operatorname{Imm}^{k \geq 2}\left(I, \mathbf{R}^{n}\right)$ be a curve with constant positive curvature, and $I_{i}$ be subintervals in a partition of $I$. Then there exists a $\mathcal{C}^{2}$-homotopy $\widetilde{f}_{t} \in$ $\operatorname{Imm}^{k}\left(I, \mathbf{R}^{n}\right)$ with constant curvature such that $\widetilde{f}_{0}=f_{0}, \widetilde{f}_{t}=f_{0}$ on $\partial I, \widetilde{T}_{t}\left(\widetilde{U}_{t}\right)=$ $T_{0}\left(U_{0}\right)$ for some neighborhoods $\widetilde{U}_{t}, U_{0}$ of $\partial I$, and $\widetilde{f}_{t}$ is nonflat on $I_{i}$ for $t \in(0,1)$.
Proof. We may assume that $\left|f_{0}^{\prime}\right|=1$. Then $\left|T_{0}^{\prime}\right|$ is the curvature of $f_{0}$. So $T_{0}$ has constant speed. Let $T_{t}:=T_{0}, T_{t}^{i}$ be the restriction of $T_{t}$ to $I_{i}$, and set $x_{i}(t):=\operatorname{ave}\left(T_{0}^{i}\right)$. Let $c:[0,1] \rightarrow \mathbf{R}$ be a continuous function such that $c(0)=1, c(t) \geq 1$, and $c(t)$ is so large outside a small neighborhoods of 0,1 that $\widetilde{\ell}_{t}^{\prime}:=c(t)\left|I_{i}\right|$ forms admissible length functions for deforming $T_{t}^{i}$ as described in Theorem 4.1. Note that if $f_{0}$ is flat, then $T_{0}$ lies in a subsphere of $\mathbf{S}^{n-1}$, i.e., the intersection of $\mathbf{S}^{n-1}$ with a subspace of $\mathbf{R}^{n}$, where it is nonflat. Thus we may apply Theorem 4.1 to $T_{t}^{i}$ with respect to $x_{i}(t)$ and $\widetilde{\ell}_{t}^{i}$ to obtain a homotopy $\widetilde{T}_{t}^{i} \in \operatorname{Imm}^{k}\left(I, \mathbf{S}^{n-1}\right)$ such that $\widetilde{T}_{t}^{i}$ is nonflat in $\mathbf{R}^{n}$ for $t \in(0,1)$, $\widetilde{T}_{t}^{i}=T_{0}$ on a neighborhood of $\partial I_{i}, \operatorname{cm}\left(\widetilde{T}_{t}^{i}\right)=\operatorname{ave}\left(T_{0}^{i}\right)$, and length $\left(\widetilde{T}_{t}^{i}\right)=c(t)\left|I_{i}\right|$. The last condition allows us to parametrize $\widetilde{T}_{t}^{i}$ with constant speed $c(t)$. Define $\widetilde{T}_{t}$ by setting it equal to $\widetilde{T}_{t}^{i}$ on each $I_{i}$. Then $\widetilde{T}_{t}\left(\widetilde{U}_{t}\right)=T_{0}\left(U_{0}\right)$ for some open neighborhoods $\widetilde{U}_{t}$ and $U_{0}$ of $\partial I$, because we had $\widetilde{T}_{t}^{i}=T_{0}$ on a neighborhood of $\partial I_{i}$ before we reparametrized $\widetilde{T}_{t}^{i}$ with constant speed. Now set $\widetilde{f}_{t}(s):=f_{0}(a)+\int_{a}^{s} \widetilde{T}_{t}$. Since $\widetilde{T}_{t}$ is nonflat on $I_{i}$ for $t \in(0,1)$, so is $\widetilde{f}_{t}$. Furthermore, since $\widetilde{T}_{t}^{i}$ has constant speed $\operatorname{ave}\left(\widetilde{T}_{t}^{i}\right)=\operatorname{cm}\left(\widetilde{T}_{t}^{i}\right)=\operatorname{ave}\left(T_{0}^{i}\right)$. So $\int_{I_{i}} \widetilde{T}_{t}=\int_{I_{i}} T_{0}$, which yields that $\int_{I} \widetilde{T}_{t}=\int_{I} T_{0}$. Thus $\widetilde{f}_{t}=f_{0}$ on $\partial I$, which completes the proof.

The last observation shows that in Theorem 2.1 we may assume that $f_{0}$ and $f_{1}$ are nonflat on any given partition $I_{i}$ of $I$. Indeed, by Corollary 4.2, $f_{0}$ and $f_{1}$ are $\mathcal{C}^{2}$-homotopic through curves of constant curvature to a pair of curves, say

$\bar{f}_{0}$ and $\bar{f}_{1}$, which are nonflat on $I_{i}$. Concatenating these homotopies with $f_{t}$, we obtain a $\mathcal{C}^{2}$-homotopy between $\bar{f}_{0}$ and $\bar{f}_{1}$ through curves of nonvanishing curvature, which after a perturbation we may assume to be nonflat by Proposition 3.2. Now if Theorem 2.1 holds when $f_{0}$ and $f_{1}$ are nonflat on $I_{i}$, then $\bar{f}_{0}$ and $\bar{f}_{1}$ may be joined by a $\mathcal{C}^{2}$-homotopy of curves of constant curvature. Concatenating this homotopy with the homotopies between $f_{0}, \bar{f}_{0}$ and $f_{1}, \bar{f}_{1}$, we obtain a $\mathcal{C}^{2}$-homotopy between $f_{0}$ and $f_{1}$ through curves of constant curvature, as desired.

Suppose now that Theorem 4.1 holds. Then we prove Theorem 2.1 as follows. Since $f_{t}$ in Theorem 2.1 has unit speed, $T_{t}=f_{t}^{\prime}$. So to have $\left|f_{t}-\bar{f}_{t}\right|_{1} \leq \varepsilon$ we must have $\left|T_{t}-\widetilde{T}_{t}\right|_{0} \leq \varepsilon$. After subdividing $I$ into finitely many subintervals $I_{i}$ we may assume that length $\left(T_{t}\left(I_{i}\right)\right)<\varepsilon$. Then $T_{t}\left(I_{i}\right)$ is contained in a ball $B$ of radius $\varepsilon$ centered at its midpoint. Now if $\widetilde{T}_{t}\left(I_{i}\right) \subset U_{\varepsilon / 2}\left(T_{i}\left(I_{i}\right)\right)$, then $\widetilde{T}_{t}\left(I_{i}\right)$ is contained in $B$ as well. So $\left|\widetilde{T}_{t}-T_{t}\right|_{0} \leq \varepsilon$ on $I_{i}$. Furthermore, by Proposition 3.2, we may assume that $f_{t}$ is nonflat on each $I_{i}$ for $t \in(0,1)$, which yields that so is $T_{t}$. As discussed above, we may also assume that $f_{0}$ and $f_{1}$ are nonflat on $I_{i}$ via Corollary 4.2. Then so are $T_{0}$ and $T_{1}$. Hence we may assume that $T_{t}$ is nonflat on $I_{i}$.

Similar to the proof of Corollary 4.2, let $T_{t}^{i}$ be the restriction of $T_{t}$ to $I_{i}$. We may apply Theorem 4.1 to $T_{t}^{i}$ with respect to $x_{i}(t):=\operatorname{ave}\left(T_{t}^{i}\right)$ and $\widetilde{\ell}_{t}^{i}=c(t)\left|I_{i}\right|$ to obtain the homotopy $\widetilde{T}_{t}^{i}$ with $\operatorname{cm}\left(\widetilde{T}_{t}^{i}\right)=\operatorname{ave}\left(T_{t}^{i}\right)$ and length $\left(\widetilde{T}_{t}^{i}\right)=c(t)\left|I_{i}\right|$. So we may assume that $\widetilde{T}_{i}$ has constant speed $c(t)$, and define $\widetilde{T}_{t}$ on $I$ by setting it equal to $\widetilde{T}_{t}^{i}$ on $I_{i}$. Next we set $\widetilde{f}_{t}(s):=f_{t}(a)+\int_{a}^{s} \widetilde{T}_{t}$. Then $\left|\widetilde{f}_{t}^{i}\right|=\left|\widetilde{T}_{t}\right|=1$. So $\widetilde{\kappa}_{t}=\left|\widetilde{T}_{t}^{i}\right|=c(t)$ as desired. Furthermore, since $\widetilde{T}_{t}^{i}$ has constant speed, $\operatorname{ave}\left(\widetilde{T}_{t}^{i}\right)=\operatorname{cm}\left(\widetilde{T}_{t}^{i}\right)=\operatorname{ave}\left(T_{t}^{i}\right)$. So $\int_{I_{i}} \widetilde{T}_{t}=\int_{I_{i}} T_{t}$, which yields that $\int_{I} \widetilde{T}_{t}=\int_{I} T_{t}$. Thus $\widetilde{f}_{t}=f_{t}$ on $\partial I$. Next note that $\left|\widetilde{f}_{t}(s)-f_{t}(s)\right| \leq \int_{a}^{s}\left|\widetilde{T}_{t}-T_{t}\right| \leq \int_{I}\left|\widetilde{T}_{t}-T_{t}\right|=\sum_{i=1}^{N} \int_{I_{i}}\left|\widetilde{T}_{t}-T_{t}\right| \leq N \varepsilon|I|$. Thus $\left|f_{t}-\widetilde{f}_{t}\right|_{0} \leq N \varepsilon|I|$. We also have $\left|f_{t}^{\prime}-\widetilde{f}_{t}^{\prime}\right|_{0}=\left|T_{t}(u)-\widetilde{T}_{t}(u)\right|_{0} \leq \varepsilon$. Hence $\left|f_{t}-\widetilde{f}_{t}\right|_{1}$ can be made arbitrarily small.

# 5. Perturbation of Geodesics 

Here we prove a very special case of Theorem 4.1 by an explicit elementary argument. A curve $f \in \operatorname{Emb}^{\infty}\left(I, \mathbf{S}^{n-1}\right)$ is a geodesic if it has constant speed and lies in a plane through the origin of $\mathbf{R}^{n}$.

Lemma 5.1. For $t \in(0,1]$, let $f_{t} \in \operatorname{Emb}^{\infty}\left(I, \mathbf{S}^{n-1}\right)$ be a $\mathcal{C}^{1}$-isotopy of geodesics of length $\ell_{t}$. Then, for any continuous family of constants $\widetilde{\ell}_{t} \succ \ell_{t}$ and $\varepsilon>0$, there exists a $\mathcal{C}^{1}$-isotopy $\widetilde{f}_{t} \in \operatorname{Emb}^{\infty}\left(I, \mathbf{S}^{n-1}\right)$ such that $\widetilde{f}_{t} \subset U_{\varepsilon}\left(f_{t}\right), \widetilde{f}_{t}=f_{t}$ on a neighborhood of $\partial I$, length $\left(\widetilde{f}_{t}\right)=\widetilde{\ell}_{t}, \operatorname{cm}\left(\widetilde{f}_{t}\right)=\operatorname{cm}\left(f_{t}\right)$, and $\widetilde{f}_{t}$ is nonflat. Furthermore if $\widetilde{\ell}_{t} / \ell_{t} \rightarrow 1$ as $t \rightarrow 0$, then $\left|\widetilde{f}_{t}-f_{t}\right|_{1} \rightarrow 0$.

Proof. We may assume that $I=[-1,1]$. After composing $f_{t}$ with a family of rotations we may also assume that $f_{t}$ lies in the plane of the first two coordinates, and $f_{t}(0)=p:=(1,0, \ldots, 0)$. So $\operatorname{cm}\left(f_{t}\right)=\left|\operatorname{cm}\left(f_{t}\right)\right| p$. Let $e_{n}$ be the standard basis of $\mathbf{R}^{n}$. We construct $\widetilde{f}_{t}$ through a sequence of $n-2$ perturbations of $f_{t}$ in the directions

$e_{3}, \ldots, e_{n}$ which increase the length by $\left(\widetilde{\ell}_{t}-\ell_{t}\right) /(n-2)$ at each step, and preserve $\operatorname{cm}\left(f_{t}\right)$. This is achieved using the $\mathcal{C}^{\infty}$ bump function $\beta_{t}: \mathbf{R} \rightarrow \mathbf{R}$ given by

$$
\beta_{t}(s):=\lambda_{t} \exp \left(\frac{-1}{\rho_{t}^{2}-s^{2}}\right) \sin \left(\omega_{t} s\right)
$$

if $-\rho_{t} \leq s \leq \rho_{t}$, and 0 otherwise. Set $\lambda_{t}:=\min \left\{\left|\widetilde{\ell}_{t}-\ell_{t}\right|, \varepsilon / 4\right\}$, and $\rho_{t}:=\min \left\{m_{t}, 1-\right.$ $\left.m_{t}\right\}$ for $m_{t} \in(0,1)$. So $\beta_{t}$ depends only on $m_{t}$ and $\omega_{t}$, which control its location and length respectively. For $s \in[0,1]$ and appropriate values of $m_{t}$ and $\omega_{t}$ specified below, we define

$$
f_{t}^{1}(s):=\frac{f_{t}(s)+\beta_{t}\left(s-m_{t}\right) e_{3}}{\left|f_{t}(s)+\beta_{t}\left(s-m_{t}\right) e_{3}\right|}
$$

if $m_{t}-\rho_{t} \leq s \leq m_{t}+\rho_{t}$, and we set $f_{t}^{1}(s):=f_{t}(s)$ otherwise. Then we extend $f_{t}^{1}$ to $[-1,1]$ by letting $f_{t}^{1}(-s)$ be the reflection $f_{t}^{1}(s)$ in $\mathbf{S}^{n-1}$ with respect to $p$. See Figure 1. Since $f_{t}^{1}$ is symmetric with respect to $p, \operatorname{cm}\left(f_{t}^{1}\right)=\left|\operatorname{cm}\left(f_{t}^{1}\right)\right| p$. Furthermore
![img-0.jpeg](img-0.jpeg)

Figure 1.
there exists a unique $\omega_{t} \geq 0$ for each $m_{t}$ such that length $\left(f_{t}^{1}\right)=\ell_{t}+\left(\widetilde{\ell}_{t}-\ell_{t}\right) /(n-2)$, since the length of (the graph of) $\beta_{t}$ increases monotonically with $\omega_{t}$. Finally note that if $m_{t}$ is close to 0 , then the bumps are close to $p$, so $\left|\operatorname{cm}\left(f_{t}^{1}\right)\right| \geq\left|\operatorname{cm}\left(f_{t}\right)\right|$ and when $m_{t}$ is close to 1 then the bumps are away from $p$ so $\left|\operatorname{cm}\left(f_{t}^{1}\right)\right| \leq\left|\operatorname{cm}\left(f_{t}\right)\right|$. It follows that there exists a unique choice for $m_{t}$ such that $\left|\operatorname{cm}\left(f_{t}^{1}\right)\right|=\left|\operatorname{cm}\left(f_{t}\right)\right|$. So we have specified a unique choice for $f_{t}^{1}$. Since the parameters $\ell_{t}, \widetilde{\ell}_{t}, \lambda_{t}, \omega_{t}, m_{t}$, and $\rho_{t}$ all depend continuously on $t, t \mapsto\left|f_{t}^{1}\right|_{1}$ is continuous. Similarly, this procedure can be continued, for $2 \leq i \leq n-2$, by setting, for $s \in[0,1]$,

$$
f_{t}^{i}(s):=\frac{f_{t}^{i-1}(s)+\beta_{t}\left(s-m_{t}\right) e_{i+2}}{\left|f_{t}^{i-1}(s)+\beta_{t}\left(s-m_{t}\right) e_{i+2}\right|}
$$

if $m_{t}-\rho_{t} \leq s \leq m_{t}+\rho_{t}$, and $f_{t}^{i}(s):=f_{t}^{i-1}(s)$ otherwise, with appropriate values of $m_{t}$ and $\omega_{t}$ at each step, as described above. Then $\widetilde{f}_{t}:=f_{t}^{n-2}$ is the desired homotopy. Finally suppose that $\widetilde{\ell}_{t} / \ell_{t} \rightarrow 1$. We want to show that then $\left|\widetilde{f}_{t}-f_{t}\right|_{1} \rightarrow 0$. To this end note that after composing $f_{t}$ and $\widetilde{f}_{t}$ with local homotheties in $\mathbf{S}^{n-1}$ centered at $p$, we may assume that $\ell_{t}$ is constant. Consequently, since $\left|\widetilde{\ell}_{t}-\ell_{t}\right| \rightarrow 0$, both the amplitude $\lambda_{t}$ and frequency $\omega_{t}$ of the bumps vanish at each step, while the width of the bumps $\rho_{t}$ is bounded below by a positive constant. Hence $\left|\widetilde{f}_{t}-f_{t}\right|_{1} \rightarrow 0$ as desired.

# 6. Parametric Carathéodory and Steinitz Theorems 

Here we prove one-parameter versions of some classical results in convex geometry needed to establish Theorem 4.1. Steinitz [26] [22, Thm. 1.3.10] showed that any point in the interior of the convex hull of a set $X \subset \mathbf{R}^{n}$ lies in the interior of the convex hull of at most $2 n$ points of $X$. We need the following analogue of that result. We say that a family of sets $S_{t}=\left\{s_{1}(t), \ldots, s_{N}(t)\right\} \subset I$ is continuous if $s_{i}(t)$ is continuous.
Lemma 6.1. Let $f_{t} \in \operatorname{Emb}^{0}\left(I, \mathbf{R}^{n \geq 3}\right)$ be a $\mathcal{C}^{0}$-homotopy, and $x:[0,1] \rightarrow \mathbf{R}^{n}$ be a continuous map with $x(t) \in \operatorname{int} \operatorname{conv}\left(f_{t}\right)$. Then there exists a continuous family $S_{t} \subset I$ of sets of $4 n$ distinct points such that $x(t) \in \operatorname{intconv}\left(f_{t}\left(S_{t}\right)\right)$.
Proof. By Steinitz theorem, for each $t \in[0,1]$ there is a collection $S_{t} \subset I$ of $2 n$ distinct points such that $x(t) \in \operatorname{intconv}\left(f_{t}\left(S_{t_{0}}\right)\right)$. By continuity of $t \mapsto f_{t}$, for each $t_{0} \in[0,1]$ we have $x(t) \in \operatorname{intconv}\left(f_{t}\left(S_{t_{0}}\right)\right)$ for $t$ close to $t_{0}$. By Lebesgue number lemma, there exists a partition $0=t_{0}<\cdots<t_{\ell}=1$ of $[0,1]$ such that $x(t) \in \operatorname{intconv}\left(f_{t}\left(S_{t_{i}}\right)\right)$ for $t \in\left[t_{i}, t_{i+1}\right]$. Let $S_{t}^{o}$ be a continuous selection of $2 n$ points such that $S_{t}^{o}=S_{t_{i}}$ whenever $t \in\left[t_{i}, t_{i+1}\right]$ and $i$ is even. Similarly let $S_{t}^{o}$ be a continuous selections of $2 n$ points such that $S_{t}^{o}=S_{t_{i}}$ whenever $t \in\left[t_{i}, t_{i+1}\right]$ and $i$ is odd. Then $S_{t}:=S^{o}(t) \cup S^{o}(t)$ gives a continuous selection of $4 n$ points which contain $x(t)$ within the interior of their convex hull; however, $S_{t}$ may contain fewer than $4 n$ points.

To complete the proof it remains to show that there is a continuous selection of $4 n$ distinct points of $I$ arbitrarily close to $S_{t}$ with respect to Hausdorff distance between subsets of $I$. Note that $S_{t}$ may be viewed as a continuous mapping $[0,1] \rightarrow I^{4 n} \subset \mathbf{R}^{4 n}$. We need to find a continuous map $\widetilde{S}_{t}:[0,1] \rightarrow I^{4 n}$, which is arbitrarily close to $S_{t}$ as a subset of $I$, and such that $\widetilde{S}_{t}$ does not intersect any of the hyperplanes $H_{i j}$ where the $i^{\text {th }}$ and $j^{\text {th }}$ coordinates of $\mathbf{R}^{4 n}$ are equal, for $1 \leq i<j \leq 4 n$. Let $H_{i j}^{ \pm}$be the closed half-spaces determined by $H_{i j}$. If any segment of $S_{t}$ lies in $H_{i j}^{-}$, we may reflect that with respect to $H_{i j}$ to obtain a mapping $\widetilde{S}_{t}$ which is contained in $H_{i j}^{+}$ (in other words, whenever two points of $S_{t}$ cross each other, then we switch their indices). So $\widetilde{S}_{t}$ and $S_{t}$ coincide as subsets of $I$. Finally, we may perturb $\widetilde{S}_{t}$ so that it lies in the interior of $H_{i j}^{+}$which yields the desired mapping $\widetilde{S}_{t}$.

Carathéodory's theorem [2] [22, Thm. 1.1.4] states that any point $x$ in the convex hull of a set $X \subset \mathbf{R}^{n}$ is a convex combination of at most $n+1$ points $p_{i}$ of $X$, i.e., there exist constants $a_{i}>0$ with $\sum_{i} a_{i}=1$ such that $x=\sum_{i} a_{i} p_{i}$. We need the following continuous version of Carathéodory's theorem:
Lemma 6.2. Let $p_{i}:[0,1] \rightarrow \mathbf{R}^{n}, i=1, \ldots, N$, be $\mathcal{C}^{k}$ maps. Suppose there exists a $\mathcal{C}^{k}$ map $x:[0,1] \rightarrow \mathbf{R}^{n}$ such that $x(t) \in \operatorname{intconv}\left(\left\{p_{i}(t)\right\}\right)$. Then there are $\mathcal{C}^{k}$ functions $a_{i}(t)$ such that $a_{i}>0, \sum_{i} a_{i}(t)=1$, and $\sum_{i} a_{i}(t) p_{i}(t)=x(t)$.
Proof. We may assume that $x(t)=0$ after replacing $p_{i}(t)$ with $p_{i}(t)-x(t)$. Then we need to find functions $a_{i}(t)$, such that $P(t) a(t)=0$, where $P(t)$ is the $n \times N$ matrix with columns $p_{i}(t)$, and $a(t)$ is the vector with components $a_{i}(t)$. So $a(t) \in \operatorname{ker}(P(t))$. By Carathéodory's theorem, there are coefficients $a^{0}\left(t_{0}\right):=\left(a_{1}^{0}\left(t_{0}\right), \ldots, a_{N}^{0}\left(t_{0}\right)\right)$

fulfilling these properties at any given point $t_{0} \in(0,1)$. We may assume that $a_{i}^{0}\left(t_{0}\right)>0$ since 0 lies in the interior of the convex hull. Note that $P(t)$ has constant rank $n$, since int $\operatorname{conv}\left(\left\{p_{i}(t)\right\}\right) \neq \emptyset$. So $\operatorname{ker}(P(t))$ has dimension $N-n$. Since $p_{i}(t)$ are $\mathcal{C}^{k}$, we may choose a $\mathcal{C}^{k}$ family of orthonormal bases $e_{j}(t)$ for $\operatorname{ker}(P(t))$ near $t_{0}$, by a theorem of Doležal $[3,23,28]$. Then the projection $a^{0}(t):=\sum\left\langle a^{0}\left(t_{0}\right), e_{j}(t)\right\rangle$ of $a^{0}\left(t_{0}\right)$ into $\operatorname{ker}(P(t))$ will be $\mathcal{C}^{k}$. Furthermore, since $a_{i}^{0}\left(t_{0}\right)>0$, we have $a_{i}^{0}(t)>0$ for $t$ near $t_{0}$. So the desired coefficients can be found locally. Thus we may cover $[0,1]$ by a finite number of open subsets where the desired coefficients exist and glue them together via a partition of unity.

Note 6.3. If $p_{i}(t)$ in the last result were constant, then the conclusion would follow immediately from a theorem of Kalman [15] who established existence of continuous barycentric coordinates inside convex polytopes.

Note 6.4. Lemma 6.1 does not hold, for any finite number of points, if we require that $x(t)$ lie only in the relative interior of $\operatorname{conv}\left(f_{t}\right)$, i.e., allow $f_{t}$ to be flat [9].

# 7. Proof of the Main Results 

Here we prove Theorem 4.1, which yields Theorems 2.1 and 1.1 as discussed above. The proof proceeds in four stages: (I) we define a certain point $\bar{x}(t)$ associated to $x(t)$, and select points $p_{i}(t)$ of $f_{t}$ which contain $\bar{x}(t)$ within their convex hull; (II) we perturb $f_{t}$ to a curve $\widetilde{f}_{t}$ which contains geodesic segments $\widetilde{g}_{t}^{i}$ near $p_{i}(t)$, see Figure 2 ; (III) we perturb $\widetilde{f}_{t}$ to the desired homotopy $\widetilde{f}_{t}$ by replacing $\widetilde{g}_{t}^{i}$ with longer curves $\widetilde{g}_{t}^{i}$ via Lemma 5.1; (IV) we verify that $\widetilde{f}_{t}$ is a $\mathcal{C}^{1}$-homotopy.
![img-1.jpeg](img-1.jpeg)

Figure 2.
(I) By the triangle inequality, we may assume that $f_{t}=f_{0}$ for $t \in[0, \eta]$, and $f_{t}=f_{1}$ for $t \in[1-\eta, 1]$ if $\eta>0$ is sufficiently small. Accordingly, we set $x(t)=x(0)$ for $t \in[0, \eta]$ and $x(t)=x(1)$ for $t \in[1-\eta, 1]$. So $x(t)=\operatorname{cm}\left(f_{t}\right)$ for $t \in[0, \eta] \cup[1-\eta, 1]$. Define $\bar{x}:[0,1] \rightarrow \mathbf{R}^{n}$ by setting $\bar{x}(0):=x(0), \bar{x}(1):=x(1)$, and

$$
\bar{x}(t):=\frac{\widetilde{\ell}_{t} x(t)-\ell_{t} \operatorname{cm}\left(f_{t}\right)}{\widetilde{\ell}_{t}-\ell_{t}}
$$

for $t \in(0,1)$. Since $x(t)=\operatorname{cm}\left(f_{t}\right)$ near 0 and $1, \bar{x}$ is continuous. Next note that as $\widetilde{\ell}_{t}$ grows large, $\bar{x}(t) \rightarrow x(t)$. So choosing $\widetilde{\ell}_{t}$ sufficiently large on $[\eta, 1-\eta]$, we can make sure that $\bar{x}(t) \in \operatorname{int} \operatorname{conv}\left(f_{t}\right)$. Now, by lemma 6.1, we may continuously choose $4 n$ distinct points $s_{i}(t) \in \operatorname{int}(I)$ such that if $p_{i}(t):=f_{t}\left(s_{i}(t)\right)$ then $\bar{x}(t) \in \operatorname{int} \operatorname{conv}\left\{p_{i}(t)\right\}$.

Thus, by Lemma 6.2, there are continuous functions $a_{i}(t)>0$ with $\sum a_{i}(t)=1$ such that

$$
\sum a_{i}(t) p_{i}(t)=\bar{x}(t)
$$

We assume that all sums range over $i=1, \ldots, 4 n$.
(II) Let $\delta:[0,1] \rightarrow \mathbf{R}$ be a continuous function with $\delta(t)>0$ for $t \in(0,1)$ and $\delta(0)=0=\delta(1)$. We may assume that $\max (\delta)$ is smaller than the smallest distance in $f_{t}$ between the points $p_{i}(t), f_{t}(a), f_{t}(b)$. Then there exist points $r_{i}(t), q_{i}(t)$ in $f_{t}$ which are at distance $\delta(t)$ from $p_{i}(t)$, as measured in $f_{t}$, and lie on different sides of $p_{i}(t)$ when $\delta(t)>0$. Let $\widehat{r_{i}(t) q_{i}(t)}$ be the segment of $f_{t}$ between $r_{i}(t)$ and $q_{i}(t)$. So

$$
\left|\widehat{r_{i}(t) q_{i}(t)}\right|=2 \delta(t)
$$

Replacing $\widehat{r_{i}(t) q_{i}(t)}$ with the geodesic segment $r_{i}(t) q_{i}(t)$ in $\mathbf{S}^{n-1}$, and reparametrizing with constant speed, yields a $\mathcal{C}^{0}$-homotopy $\widehat{f}_{t} \in \operatorname{Imm}^{0}\left(I, \mathbf{S}^{n}\right)$. Since $f_{t}$ is $\mathcal{C}^{1}$, $\left|\widehat{r_{i}(t) q_{i}(t)}\right| /\left|r_{i}(t) q_{i}(t)\right| \rightarrow 1$ as $\delta(t) \rightarrow 0$. Thus, if $\max (\delta)$ is sufficiently small, we can make sure that $\left|r_{i}(t) q_{i}(t)\right|>\delta(t)$. Let $\bar{g}_{t}^{i}$ be the subsegment of $r_{i}(t) q_{i}(t)$ of length $\left|\bar{g}_{t}^{i}\right|=a_{i}(t) \delta(t)$ centered at the midpoint of $r_{i}(t) q_{i}(t)$. So $\bar{g}_{0}^{i}=p_{i}(0)$. If we set $\bar{g}_{t}:=\cup_{i} \bar{g}_{t}^{i}$, then we may record that

$$
\left|\bar{g}_{t}\right|=\delta(t), \quad \text { and } \quad\left|\bar{g}_{t}^{i}\right|=a_{i}(t)\left|\bar{g}_{t}\right|
$$

Furthermore, we set

$$
\bar{p}_{i}(t):=\operatorname{cm}\left(\bar{g}_{t}^{i}\right)
$$

Next we smoothen $\widehat{f}_{t}$ by rounding off its corners at $r_{i}(t)$ and $q_{i}(t)$ as follows. Let $I^{\prime} \subset \operatorname{int}(I)$ be a subsegment so large that $\widehat{f}_{t}\left(I^{\prime}\right)$ contains all segments $r_{i}(t) q_{i}(t)$, $\phi: I \rightarrow \mathbf{R}$ be a $\mathcal{C}^{\infty}$ (bump) function such that $0 \leq \phi \leq 1, \phi>0$ on $I^{\prime}$ and $\phi=0$ near $\partial I$, and $\theta_{t}: \mathbf{R} \rightarrow \mathbf{R}$ be a continuous family of symmetric $\mathcal{C}^{\infty}$ functions with $\theta_{t} \geq 0, \int_{I} \theta_{t}(s) d s=1$ and compact support $\operatorname{supp}\left(\theta_{t}\right)$. Now define

$$
\bar{f}_{t}:=\frac{\phi\left(\widehat{f}_{t} * \theta_{t}\right)+(1-\phi) \widehat{f}_{t}}{\left|\phi\left(\widehat{f}_{t} * \theta_{t}\right)+(1-\phi) \widehat{f}_{t}\right|}
$$

Then $\bar{f}_{t} \in \operatorname{Imm}^{k}\left(I, \mathbf{S}^{n-1}\right)$, and assuming $\operatorname{supp}\left(\theta_{t}\right)$ is sufficiently small, we have $\bar{g}_{t}^{i} \subset \bar{f}_{t}$. Since $\left|\widehat{f}_{t}-f_{t}\right|_{0} \rightarrow 0$ as $\delta(t) \rightarrow 0,1,\left|\widehat{f}_{t} * \theta_{t}-f_{t}\right|_{1} \rightarrow 0$, which in turn yields that $\left|\bar{f}_{t}-f_{t}\right|_{1} \rightarrow 0$ as $\delta(t) \rightarrow 0,1$. Furthermore, if we set $\bar{\ell}_{t}:=\operatorname{length}\left(\bar{f}_{t}\right)$ and $\bar{\ell}_{t}:=\operatorname{length}\left(\widehat{f}_{t}\right)$, then $\bar{\ell}_{t} \rightarrow \bar{\ell}_{t}$ as $\operatorname{supp}\left(\theta_{t}\right) \rightarrow 0$. So assuming $\operatorname{supp}\left(\theta_{t}\right)$ is sufficiently small, we have

$$
\left|\bar{\ell}_{t}-\ell_{t}\right| \leq 2\left|\bar{\ell}_{t}-\ell_{t}\right|=2 \sum\left(\left|\widehat{r_{i}(t) q_{i}(t)}\right|-\left|r_{i}(t) q_{i}(t)\right|\right)
$$

(III) Now we construct the desired homotopy $\widehat{f}_{t}$ by applying Lemma 5.1 to deform each segment $\bar{g}_{t}^{i}$ of $\bar{f}_{t}$ to a canonical curve $\widetilde{g}_{t}^{i}$ with appropriate length $\left|\widetilde{g}_{t}^{i}\right|$ so that $\operatorname{cm}\left(\widetilde{f}_{t}\right)=x(t)$ and length $\left(\widetilde{f}_{t}\right)=\bar{\ell}_{t}$. Set $\widetilde{g}_{t}:=\cup_{i} \widetilde{g}_{t}^{i}$. Then $\widetilde{f}_{t} \backslash \widetilde{g}_{t}=\bar{f}_{t} \backslash \bar{g}_{t}$, which yields

$$
\left|\widetilde{g}_{t}\right|=\bar{\ell}_{t}-\bar{\ell}_{t}+\left|\bar{g}_{t}\right|
$$

Since $\widetilde{\ell}_{t}$ can be made arbitrarily close to $\widetilde{\ell}_{t}$ which is smaller than $\ell_{t}$ for $t \in(0,1)$, we may assume that $\widetilde{\ell}_{t}<\ell_{t}$ for $t \in(0,1)$ by choosing $\operatorname{supp}\left(\theta_{t}\right)$ sufficiently small, which yields that $\left|\widetilde{g}_{t}\right|>\left|\bar{g}_{t}\right|$ for $t \in(0,1)$. So, by Lemma 5.1, we may require that $\widetilde{g}_{t}$ and consequently $\widetilde{f}_{t}$ be nonflat in $\mathbf{S}^{n+m-1}$ for $t \in(0,1)$, as desired. Next note that, by Lemma 5.1, $\operatorname{cm}\left(\widetilde{g}_{t}^{i}\right)=\operatorname{cm}\left(\bar{g}_{t}^{i}\right)=\bar{p}_{i}(t)$. Thus

$$
\begin{aligned}
\operatorname{cm}\left(\widetilde{f}_{t}\right) & =\sum \frac{\left|\widetilde{g}_{t}^{i}\right|}{\widetilde{\ell}_{t}} \operatorname{cm}\left(\widetilde{g}_{t}^{i}\right)+\frac{\widetilde{\ell}_{t}-\left|\widetilde{g}_{t}\right|}{\widetilde{\ell}_{t}} \operatorname{cm}\left(\widetilde{f}_{t} \backslash \widetilde{g}_{t}\right) \\
& =\sum \frac{\left|\widetilde{g}_{t}^{i}\right|}{\widetilde{\ell}_{t}} \bar{p}_{i}(t)+\frac{\widetilde{\ell}_{t}-\left|\bar{g}_{t}\right|}{\widetilde{\ell}_{t}} \operatorname{cm}\left(\bar{f}_{t} \backslash \bar{g}_{t}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Setting the last expression above equal to $x(t)$ we obtain

$$
\sum \frac{\left|\widetilde{g}_{t}^{i}\right|}{\left|\widetilde{g}_{t}\right|} \bar{p}_{i}(t)=\frac{\widetilde{\ell}_{t} x(t)-\left(\widetilde{\ell}_{t}-\left|\bar{g}_{t}\right|\right) \operatorname{cm}\left(\bar{f}_{t} \backslash \bar{g}_{t}\right)}{\left|\widetilde{g}_{t}\right|}
$$

for $t \in(0,1)$. Thus $\operatorname{cm}\left(\widetilde{f}_{t}\right)=x(t)$ provided that we find values for $\left|\widetilde{g}_{t}^{i}\right|$ so that (5) holds. Note that, as $\delta(t) \rightarrow 0, \operatorname{cm}\left(\bar{f}_{t} \backslash \bar{g}_{t}\right) \rightarrow \operatorname{cm}\left(f_{t}\right), \widetilde{\ell}_{t}-\left|\widetilde{g}_{t}\right| \rightarrow \ell_{t}$, and $\left|\widetilde{g}_{t}\right| \rightarrow \widetilde{\ell}_{t}-\ell_{t}$. So the right hand side of (5) which we call $\widetilde{x}(t)$ converges to $\bar{x}(t)$, and thus lies in int conv $\left\{p_{i}(t)\right\}$ if $\max (\delta)$ is sufficiently small. On the other hand $\bar{p}_{i}(t) \rightarrow p_{i}(t)$. So assuming $\max (\delta)$ is sufficiently small, we have

$$
\widetilde{x}(t) \in \operatorname{int} \operatorname{conv}\left\{\bar{p}_{i}(t)\right\}
$$

for $t \in(0,1)$. If we set $\widetilde{x}(0):=x(0), \widetilde{x}(1):=x(1)$, then $\widetilde{x}$ is continuous on $[0,1]$, and the above inclusion still holds at $t=0,1$, since $\bar{p}_{i}(0)=\bar{g}_{0}^{i}=p_{i}(0)$ and $\bar{p}_{i}(1)=\bar{g}_{1}^{i}=p_{i}(1)$ by definition. Thus, by Lemma 6.2, there are continuous functions $\widetilde{a}_{i}(t)>0$ with $\sum \widetilde{a}_{i}(t)=1$ such that $\sum \widetilde{a}_{i}(t) \bar{p}_{i}(t)=\widetilde{x}(t)$. Hence if we set

$$
\left|\widetilde{g}_{t}^{i}\right|:=\widetilde{a}_{i}(t)\left|\widetilde{g}_{t}\right|
$$

then (5) holds and we obtain $\operatorname{cm}\left(\widetilde{f}_{t}\right)=x(t)$ as desired.
(IV) It remains to check that $\widetilde{f}_{t}$ is a $\mathcal{C}^{1}$-homotopy, i.e., $\left|\widetilde{f}_{t}-f_{0}\right|_{1} \rightarrow 0$ as $t \rightarrow 0$. To this end note that $\left|\widetilde{f}_{t}-f_{0}\right|_{1} \leq\left|\widetilde{f}_{t}-\bar{f}_{t}\right|_{1}+\left|\bar{f}_{t}-f_{0}\right|_{1}$ and $\left|\bar{f}_{t}-f_{0}\right|_{1} \rightarrow 0$ as we discussed in Part II above. So we just need to show that $\left|\widetilde{f}_{t}-\bar{f}_{t}\right|_{1} \rightarrow 0$, which is the case provided that $\left|\widetilde{g}_{t}^{i}-g_{t}^{i}\right|_{1} \rightarrow 0$. Thus, by Lemma 5.1, it suffices to check that $\left|\widetilde{g}_{t}^{i}\right| /\left|\bar{g}_{t}^{i}\right| \rightarrow 1$, as $t \rightarrow 0,1$. Note that, for $t \in(0,1)$,

$$
\frac{\left|\widetilde{g}_{t}^{i}\right|}{\left|\bar{g}_{t}^{i}\right|}=\frac{\widetilde{a}_{i}(t)\left|\widetilde{g}_{t}\right|}{a_{i}(t)\left|\bar{g}_{t}\right|}=\frac{\widetilde{a}_{i}(t)}{a_{i}(t)}\left(\frac{\left|\widetilde{\ell}_{t}-\widetilde{\ell}_{t}\right|}{\delta(t)}+1\right)
$$

Furthermore, we have

$$
\frac{\widetilde{\ell}_{t}-\widetilde{\ell}_{t}}{\delta(t)} \leq \frac{\left|\widetilde{\ell}_{t}-\ell_{t}\right|}{\delta(t)}+\frac{\left|\ell_{t}-\widetilde{\ell}_{t}\right|}{\delta(t)}
$$

We can make sure that $\left(\widetilde{\ell}_{t}-\ell_{t}\right) / \delta(t)$ vanishes as $t \rightarrow 0,1$, by setting $\delta(t) \geq\left(\widetilde{\ell}_{t}-\ell_{t}\right)^{1 / 2}$ for $t$ close to 0,1 . This is possible since $\widetilde{\ell}_{0}=\ell_{0}, \widetilde{\ell}_{1}=\ell_{1}$, and all other constraints

for $\delta(t)$ mentioned above where positive upper bounds for $\max (\delta)$. Next note that by (4),

$$
\frac{\ell_{t}-\widetilde{\ell}_{t}}{\delta(t)}=2 \frac{\ell_{t}-\widetilde{\ell}_{t}}{\left|\overline{r_{i}(t) q_{i}(t)}\right|} \leq 4 \sum\left(1-\frac{\left|r_{i}(t) q_{i}(t)\right|}{\left|\overline{r_{i}(t) q_{i}(t)}\right|}\right)
$$

Since $\delta(0)=0=\delta(1),\left|\overline{r_{i}(t) q_{i}(t)}\right| \rightarrow 0$ as $t \rightarrow 0,1$. Thus, since $f_{t}$ is $\mathcal{C}^{1}$, the right hand side of the last expression above vanishes as $t \rightarrow 0,1$. Hence $\left|\widetilde{g}_{t}\right| /\left|\widetilde{g}_{t}\right| \rightarrow 1$. Now it suffices to note that $\widetilde{a}_{i}\left(t_{0}\right)=a_{i}\left(t_{0}\right)$, for $t_{0}=0,1$. Indeed by definition $\widetilde{a}_{i}\left(t_{0}\right)$ are barycentric coordinates of $\widetilde{x}\left(t_{0}\right)=x\left(t_{0}\right)=\bar{x}\left(t_{0}\right)$, with respect to $p_{i}\left(t_{0}\right)$. Furthermore, $a_{i}(t)$ are the coordinates of $\bar{x}(t)$ with respect to $p_{i}(t)$, which completes the proof.

abstract:
We prove that curves of constant curvature satisfy the parametric $C^1$-dense
relative $h$-principle in the space of immersed curves with nonvanishing
curvature in Euclidean space $R^{n\geq 3}$. It follows that two knots of
constant curvature in $R^3$ are isotopic, resp. homotopic, through curves of
constant curvature if and only if they are isotopic, resp. homotopic, and their
self-linking numbers, resp. self-linking numbers mod $2$, are equal.
